headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. Good morning, everyone. Welcome, and thank you for joining us for Allegion's fourth Quarter And Full year 2018 Earnings Call. With me today are Dave Petratis, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Patrick Shannon, Senior V
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. Good morning, everyone. Welcome, and thank you for joining us for Allegion's fourth Quarter And Full year 2018 Earnings Call. With me today are Dave Petratis, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Patrick Shannon, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Allegion. Our earnings release, which was issued earlier this morning and the presentation, whichrefer to today's call are available on our website at allegion.com. This call will be recorded and archived on our website.
Please go to Slides #2 and 3. Statements made in today's call that are not historical facts are considered forward-looking statements and are made pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of federal securities laws. 
Please see our most recent SEC filings for a description of some of the factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from our projections. The company assumes no obligation to update these forward-looking statements. Today's presentation and commentary include non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the reconciliation in the financial tables of our press release for further details. 
Dave and Patrick will now discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2018 results and provide an outlook for 2019, which will be followed by a Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] 
Please go to Slide 4, and I'll now turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. Allegion saw another quarter of strong top line revenue growth with strength across all regions. The Americas saw strong volumes in the nonresidential business as end-market fundamentals co
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. Allegion saw another quarter of strong top line revenue growth with strength across all regions. 
The Americas saw strong volumes in the nonresidential business as end-market fundamentals continue to be positive, particularly in institutional verticals. 
EMEIA and Asia Pacific saw organic growth rates in the mid-single digits. Acquisitions continue to be to contribute to the total company revenue growth. Our electronics growth moderated in the fourth quarter with the Americas seeing approximately 7% growth. 
Residential electronics performed well. However, the nonresidential electronics growth decelerated due to the timing of large orders. 
We had full year electronics growth of high-teens in the Americas with strength in both parts of the business. We see the electronics outlook continue to be a long-term positive trend as more and more products become connected for ease of access. 
As I stated earlier, nonresidential U.S. end markets remain healthy with particular strength in institutional verticals. We do see residential new construction softening that we expect us to be mitigated by electronics and channel initiatives to drive above-market growth. 
The quartersaw continued inflationary pressures, which we believe will ease in 2019. Commodities have leveled off, and we project have another solid year in the price realization with particular strength in our Americas nonresidential businesses. In the fourth quarter, we delivered nearly 10% adjusted EPS growth, bringing the full year expansion to approximately 14% as we drove a robust 37% increase in available cash flow, which totaled more than $400 million for the year.
Overall, I'm extremely pleased with the revenue performance in both the quarter and the full year. Additionally, while operating margins could have been better, I'm satisfied with the growth in EPS that we delivered in the quarter and the full year.
Please go to Slide 5, and I'll walk through the fourth quarter financial summary. 
In Q4, Allegion delivered strong top line revenue growth. Revenue for the fourth quarter was $702.4 million, an increase of 12.4%, inclusive of organic growth of 6.7%. Acquisitions also contributed to the top line revenue expansion, offsetting the slightly unfavorable currency impact.
All regions grew organically. Americas has led the way with organic growth of 7.6% in the quarter, driven by strength in our nonresidential business. The EMEIA region saw organic growth of 4.3%, driven by performance in the SimonsVoss and Interflex businesses. Asia Pacific had a nice quarter of organic growth coming in at 4.6% against the tough comparables.
Adjusted operating margin decreased by 130 basis points due to the dilution related to the acquisitions made in 2018. Excluding the impact of these acquisitions, the base operating margins were up 20 basis points. 
Inflationary headwinds continue to pressure margins and exceeded price and productivity in the quarter. The company is committed to driving price realization and productivity actions, such that for 2019, the price productivity inflation dynamic is expected to be positive, helping to drive margin expansion across all regions of the business.
Adjusted earnings per share of $1.22 increased $0.11 or nearly 10% versus the prior year. The increase was driven by higher operating income, along with a favorable year-over-year tax rate. Available cash flow for the year came in over $408 million, an increase of 31% over prior year. Increased earnings and the nonrecurring 2017 discretionary pension funding drove the increase. Please go to Slide 6.
Before I turn the call over to Patrick, I want to talk a little about some of the things we're doing in the Connected Home Space. In 2015, Schlage with the first Smart Locks to respond to open my watch. include is the with the key by Amazon have and ring devices without even WiFi. It's built right into the lock. With Schlage Encode, we took a different approach to development. Starting first with the connected home platform and developing the lock around the desired user experience. The user first approach is part of our strategic plan to develop and integrate with leaders in connected home platforms. 
In addition, we recently announced the Schlage Connect Z-Wave plus enhancement and its compatibility with the room and Schlage Connect Zigbee-certified locks with support home automation systems. 
Our deep experience in connected home security has made us go-to partner for a wide variety of platforms and home automation solutions, including Amazon, Ring, alarm.com, Google and Apple. We will continue to build relationships to benefit consumers and accelerate adoptions of Schlage Smart Locks. Patrick will now walk you through the financial results, and I'll be back to update you on our full year 2019 outlook.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call this morning. If you would please go to Slide #7. This slide depicts the components of our revenue growth for the fourth quarter as well as the full year of 2018. Our focus on the to
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call this morning. If you would please go to Slide #7. This slide depicts the components of our revenue growth for the fourth quarter as well as the full year of 2018. Our focus on the total Allegion results and cover the regions on their respective slides.
As indicated, we delivered 6.7% organic growth in the fourth quarter. This performance reflects another strong quarter in the Americas region, which delivered 7.6% organic growth, led by the nonresidential markets. 
EMEIA and Asia Pacific saw our continued momentum with mid-single digit organic growth. Pricing for Allegion in the quarter came in at 1.5%. The company will continue to take necessary pricing actions to help mitigate the impact of ongoing inflationary pressures and any additional tariff impacts. Also, during the fourth quarter, acquisitions contributed more than 7% growth, and foreign currency was a slight headwind in all 3 regions.
With the fourth quarter performance, you can see where we ended up for the full year on revenue growth. We delivered more than 13% total revenue growth with double-digit top line growth in all 3 regions. Organic growth came in at 6%, led by the Americas at nearly 7%. 
Please go to Slide #8.
Reported net revenues for the fourth quarter were $702.4 million. As stated earlier, this reflects an increase of 12.7% versus the prior year, up 6.7% on an organic basis. 
Our adjusted operating income of $145.2 million, increased nearly 6% over the same time frame from last year. 
Adjusted operating margin of 20.7% decreased 130 basis points with a decrease driven by dilution from acquisitions. Excluding the 2018 acquisitions, adjusted operating margin on the base business was up 20 basis points year-over-year.
Total inflation exceeded price plus productivity by approximately $2.5 million and was dilutive to our adjusted operating margins by 70 basis points. We are committed to driving the price, productivity, inflation dynamics positive in 2019 to the following actions: price realization, improved productivity and operational efficiencies, acquisition integration performance, and softening inflation during the year. 
Other headwinds to margin performance were incremental investments, which had a 40 basis points impact on adjusted operating margins. As discussed, these incremental investments accelerate top line growth.
Please go to Slide #9. This slide reflects our EPS reconciliation for the fourth quarter. For the fourth quarter of 2017, reported earnings per share was $0.10. Adjusting $1.01 for the prior year restructuring expenses, integration costs related acquisitions, charges related to U.S. Tax Reform and debt refinancing, the 2017 adjusted earnings per share was $1.11. 
Operational results increased earnings per share by $0.10 as variable price, operating leverage on incremental volume and productivity more than offset inflationary impact.
Favorable year-over-year tax rate drove another $0.07 with the variability driven primarily by lower tax rate associated with tax reform, along with favorable discrete items. 
Acquisitions were a $0.01 drag in the quarter reflecting anticipated performance associated with QMI acquisition in Europe. The impact of incremental investments in the quarter was a $0.02 reduction. These incremental investments for new product development, channel strategies and demand creation spending continue to drive above-market growth and are providing solid returns on our investment. The combination of interest expense other income and noncontrolling expenses decreased earnings per share by $0.03. These results in adjusted fourth quarter 2018 earnings per share of $1.22, an increase of $0.11 or nearly 10% compared to the prior year period.
Lastly, we have a $0.17 per share benefit, primarily driven by adjustments to the provisions related to the enactment of tax reform, which more than offset reductions for charges related to acquisition and restructuring. After giving effect to these onetime items, you arrive at fourth quarter 2018 reported earnings per share of $1.39.
Please go to Slide #10. Fourth quarter revenues for the Americas region were $492.7 million, up 13% on a reported basis, and 7.6% organically. The organic growth was driven by strong volume in the nonresidential business as well as continued pricing benefits. The net earnings growth for the quarter was approximately 7%. Residential Electronics in the quarter performed well. However, nonresidential electronics growth decelerated due to timing of large orders. For the full year, growth in electronics products were solid coming in at high-teens with the strength of both residential and nonresidential products. Price realization in the quarter was 1.5%. Pricing in the nonresidential business was strong, offset by residential promotional activities.
The nonresidential business grew low double digits excluding acquisitions. Residential growth was flat in the quarter with strength in electronics, offset by some cannibalization of the mechanical business. Acquisitions added nearly 6% to total revenue.
Americas adjusted operating income of $131.8 million increased 5.3% versus the prior year period and adjusted operating margin for the quarter decreased 190 basis points. The 2018 acquisitions continue to be dilutive as expected, and had a 120 basis point impact. Inflation incremental investments exceeded price plus productivity in the quarter. Strong volume leverage and positive earnings partially offset these impacts.
Pleased go to Slide #11. Fourth quarter revenues for the EMEIA region were $157.4 million, up 4.4% and up 4.3% on an organic basis. The organic growth was driven by solid pricing for the quarter and strength in electronics led by the SimonsVoss and Interflex businesses. The impact of acquisitions offset currency headwinds.
EMEIA adjusted operating income of $22.5 million decreased approximately 10% versus the prior year period. Adjusted operating margin for the quarter decreased 230 basis points, driven primarily by dilution from acquisitions. 
As stated earlier, the poor acquisition performance was driven by our QMI business, which experienced reduced revenues in a challenging market environment, a significant mix shift to lower-margin business, along with some operational inefficiencies.
We have identified areas of opportunity and have commenced plans to get the QMI business back to profitability. Operational performance improvement will gradually occur throughout the course of 2019. 
In addition, inflation and incremental investments slightly exceeded price plus productivity. Strong volume leverage offsets these some of these unfavorable impact. 
Please go to Slide #12.
Fourth quarter revenues for the Asia Pacific region were $52.3 million, up 44.9% versus the prior year. Organic revenue continue to rebound, growing nicely at 4.6% against a tough comparable. Total revenue growth was driven by the GWA door and access business acquisition. Foreign currency was a headwind for the quarter. 
Asia Pacific adjusted operating income for the quarter was $6.5 million, an increase of nearly $2 million with adjusted operating margins down 60 basis points versus the prior year period. Dilution from acquisitions drove the margin decline. The base business adjusted operating margins were up 120 basis points with price and productivity more than offsetting the unfavorable impacts from inflation, and incremental investments.
Good volume leverage was able to offset negative mix. Please go to Slide #13.
Available cash flow for 2018 came in at $408.7 million, which is an increase of $110.8 million compared to the prior year period. The increase was driven by higher net earnings, along with the nonrecurring $50 million discretionary pension funding payment that was made in the first quarter of 2017. 
Available cash flow continues to remain strong and exceeded prior estimates. Working capital as a percent of revenues increased slightly in fourth quarter 2018, when compared to the prior year period. The increase is primarily driven by working capital related to the recently acquired businesses. And while working capital as a percent of revenue saw slight increase, we did see a reduction in the cash conversion cycle. As always, we remain committed to an effective and efficient use of working capital, and we'll continue to evaluate opportunities to minimize investments in working capital and increase available cash flow. 
I will now hand the call back over to Dave for review our full year 2019 outlook.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patrick. Please go to Slide #14. We continue to see favorable trends on our primary end markets in 2019. And as our expectation that the organic investments, combined with our ability to execute will, again, deliver better than market growth. W
componenttext:
Thank you, Patrick. Please go to Slide #14. We continue to see favorable trends on our primary end markets in 2019. And as our expectation that the organic investments, combined with our ability to execute will, again, deliver better than market growth. We also believe the electronic portfolio will continue to outpace mechanical in all regions, and we're well positioned to continue to take advantage of this industry trend. In the Americas, we see continued positive fundamentals in our nonresidential verticals led by the institutional markets. We expect the general trend toward electronic products to continue, which help mitigate the softening that we are expecting in residential new construction. 
With these expectations, we project organic revenue growth in the Americas of 5% to 6%. We are projecting Americas total revenue expansion to also be 5% to 6% with any remaining impact from the 2018 acquisitions to be offset by currency headwinds.
For the EMEIA region, we expect strength in our electronics business to more than offset weaknesses in southern Europe and the United Kingdom. 
For the region, we project organic growth of 2.5% to 4.5%. Currency headwinds are expected to more than offset acquisition benefits, bringing expected total revenue in EMEIA region to flat to 2%. 
In Asia Pacific, we continued to see a healthy growth in China with softening markets in Australia and New Zealand. 
Organic growth in the region is estimated to be 4% to 6%, and total revenue growth is estimated to be 22% to 24%, reflecting the full year impact of the acquisition of Gainsborough Hardware and API. 
All in, we are projecting total growth of the company at 5% to 6% and our organic growth also of 5% to 6%. Please go to Slide 15.
Our 2019 outlook for adjusted earnings per share is $4.75 to $4.90, an increase of approximately 6% to 9%. 
As indicated, the earnings increase is driven by revenue growth and operational improvements as adjusted operating earnings are expected to increase 10% to 14%. 
Inflationary pressures will continue to be a headwind in the first half of the year, but we anticipate pricing and productivity actions to help drive margin expansion for 2019.
Incremental investments continue to be a headwind as we continue to focus on accelerating new product development and channel initiatives, which we believe, enable us to keep delivery above-market growth and allowing us to take advantage of the shifting customer preference is to electronic products.
Other expenses are expected to be a drag on EPS, primarily driven by pension expense. Our outlook assumes a full year effective tax rate of approximately 16%, an increase from 13.5% in 2018, an outstanding diluted shares of approximately 95.5 million. 
The outlook also includes a $0.15 per share impact from restructuring charges and acquisition-related cost during the year. 
As a result, reporting EPS is estimated to be $4.60 million to $4.70. We are projecting our available cash flow for 2019 to be in the $430 million to $450 million range. Please go to Slide 16.
We are very pleased with our 2018 top line growth delivered organic revenue expansion of 6%, driven by electronics which you see is a positive trend for us in the future. While operating margin could have been better, we did deliver full year adjusted EPS growth of nearly 14% in 2018, and we saw a robust 37% increase in available cash flow to more than $400 million.
As we look to 2019, we expect to drive continued organic growth of above market. We also expect to deliver solid growth in adjusted EPS and generate substantial available cash flow. We are well positioned for 2019 and are committed to make the world safer, securing the places where people thrive.
I want to finish by saying that 2018 also marks the Allegion's first 5 years as an independent company. 
From the beginning, we told customers, shareholders and employees we would deliver sustained profitable growth and greater value. We have delivered industry-leading organic growth at our 5-year CAGR of 5.6%. 
We had industry-leading margins. We have focused on the safety of our employees, health of our employees and employee engagement. We've invested in the business, especially in electronics and are positioned nicely for the future. Allegion is a company, our shareholders can be proud to own. Now Patrick, and I will be happy to take your questions.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: This is Josh in for Tim. Just wanted to ask about the Americas segment, the pricing versus productivity and inflation comparison seems to be more challenging this quarter. I know you mentioned residential price dynamic, but just wondering what were some o
componenttext: This is Josh in for Tim. Just wanted to ask about the Americas segment, the pricing versus productivity and inflation comparison seems to be more challenging this quarter. I know you mentioned residential price dynamic, but just wondering what were some of the important drivers behind that. Did the higher raw material costs start to flow through the balance sheet, just kind of give us some color on that would be great.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Josh, I would characterize it as follows: we commented really good strength in pricing in the commercial area. Pricing and residential was lower than it's anticipated, primarily due to promotional activities and some rebates and those types of thi
componenttext: Yes, so Josh, I would characterize it as follows: we commented really good strength in pricing in the commercial area. Pricing and residential was lower than it's anticipated, primarily due to promotional activities and some rebates and those types of things, and that ebbs and flows during the course of the year occasionally. So a little bit lower pricing than anticipated in the residential slide. On the productivity, continue to get good productivity, particularly on materials. Inflation was more than anticipated, not so much on the raw materials, but more on the nonmaterial side. So inefficiencies associated with nonmaterials on manufacturing, those type of things. As we look forward to 2019, we believe, we have a very strong pipeline in terms of productivity, on both material and productivity projects from a manufacturing perspective. The dynamic will become positive in 2019, and it will continue to get better during the course of the year, particularly on the inflation side, where as you know, the commodities have kind of stabilized today relative to where they were in Q3. But it starts almost become deflation in the second half of the year. So that will benefit us as we progress throughout 2019.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And for my follow up, could I ask about the electronics growth? You mentioned a larger order within the commercial side. I guess, is it one large project in the prior year or some distributor dynamics, just some color on what drove that? And
componenttext: Okay, great. And for my follow up, could I ask about the electronics growth? You mentioned a larger order within the commercial side. I guess, is it one large project in the prior year or some distributor dynamics, just some color on what drove that? And how to think about electronics growth kind of going into next year?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, so really good continued strong growth in resi electronics, it was more of a tough top relative to last year on the nonresi side. But as we look forward, again, to 2019, I don't see any reason why we can't sustain kind of mid-teens electronics growth
componenttext: Yes, so really good continued strong growth in resi electronics, it was more of a tough top relative to last year on the nonresi side. But as we look forward, again, to 2019, I don't see any reason why we can't sustain kind of mid-teens electronics growth across our portfolio. Feel really good, where we're positioned, particularly when we look at some of our new products that we've introduced earlier this year. We -- Dave talked about Encode and we think that's going to go well for us we've got some other things in the pipeline going forward. So we think we're well positioned to continue to take advantage of this trend. And as you know, it's still low penetration rates overall, from a residential adoption and new homes, and so. So we think that will continue to drive our performance.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Josh, I would just add, in the institutional commercial, you can get several to be large project, where you go in and retrofit an entire building or campus. This is what we saw. We continue to be extremely motivated by the growth that we see in electronic
componenttext: Josh, I would just add, in the institutional commercial, you can get several to be large project, where you go in and retrofit an entire building or campus. This is what we saw. We continue to be extremely motivated by the growth that we see in electronics and Allegion's position as we go forward.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019

componenttext: Next question comes from Julian Mitchell with Barclays.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Maybe my first question just around following up on pricing. I think, pricing was a bit less than the gross tailwind in the Q4 than Q3. It was up, I think, 1.5 points prior quarter it was just over 2% year-on-year. So maybe just give a bit more color on w
componenttext: Maybe my first question just around following up on pricing. I think, pricing was a bit less than the gross tailwind in the Q4 than Q3. It was up, I think, 1.5 points prior quarter it was just over 2% year-on-year. So maybe just give a bit more color on why that happens on the extent of those promotional activities that you'd just mentioned? And whether you've seen any change in competitive dynamics in any portion of the market in the Americas?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Q4 pricing was anticipated to be sequentially down relative to Q3, and the reason for that is, because in Q3, we basically had the effect of 2 price increases, and remember, we pulled forward the price increase at the beginning of the quarter and
componenttext: Yes. So Q4 pricing was anticipated to be sequentially down relative to Q3, and the reason for that is, because in Q3, we basically had the effect of 2 price increases, and remember, we pulled forward the price increase at the beginning of the quarter and 2017, you had a price increase that went into effect in August, and so you had effect of 2 price increases, if you will, for one of the months in the quarter. So the expectation was that the pricing was going to come down sequentially. 1.5% is still pretty strong. When we look at how the rest of the market is performing. Commercial, we continue to perform extremely well, very pleased with how the team is pushing price there and remaining competitive on bid code activity. Decline may be a little bit lighter than expected, and again, it relates to the residential business on the promotional activities and the sell-through to the consumer. So I don't look at that as a necessary a longer-term impact going to 2019 would expect pricing to remain robust and would expect us to be able to deliver kind of the 1.5% increase year-over-year in 2019 relative to 2018.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: And then my second question would really be about the residential business in the Americas in terms of market landscape. Maybe just clarify how much of your Americas business for 2018 as a whole was residential? And what do you expect the residential piec
componenttext: And then my second question would really be about the residential business in the Americas in terms of market landscape. Maybe just clarify how much of your Americas business for 2018 as a whole was residential? And what do you expect the residential piece of your business to grow in 2019?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: So I think, about our residential position about 30%. As we look at '19, the new construction elements of the residential market will be softening, I think, that's well understood. We have in the retrofit side of it, which is our strongest position with o
componenttext: So I think, about our residential position about 30%. As we look at '19, the new construction elements of the residential market will be softening, I think, that's well understood. We have in the retrofit side of it, which is our strongest position with our new electronic products, we believe that will give us good opportunities for growth. It's really how we've been positioning the company. In a single-family multi-family, electronic penetration is low single digits, and we're growing well above that, and we think it's sets us up nicely. We have also in our channel initiatives had some success, winning some large contracts with top builders, and we think overall we'll setup for a nice year in a softer residential environment.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019

componenttext: And the next question comes from Joshua Pokrzywinski with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: Just a follow-up on the resi question there. Did you see anything in the fourth quarter in terms of destock around the shifting landscape in, in that channel just it seems like the market share landscape is shifting a little bit notably that the competitor has had some success with some of their offerings. So I'm just wondering how much of what you're seeing is response to the new market versus some channel fill by some other folks. Just trying to get my hands around how much of this is short-term noise versus something that's more of a market-driven weakness over time?

componenttext: I think, in terms of the big box, there was some shifting in terms of the timing of orders as they saw deceleration in the of the market. We do see new competitors coming into the electronics base around. I think if you walk through the consumer electronics show, there's many new entries. I think, a number of announcements in enhancements that we made to our product portfolio in terms of connectivity as well as our channel initiatives, it positions us nicely for 2019.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then, on the 2019 implied margin guidance, Patrick, it looks like relative to the way you guys have framed up operating leverage historically that there is called an extra 10 points of incremental margin or maybe $10 million of
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then, on the 2019 implied margin guidance, Patrick, it looks like relative to the way you guys have framed up operating leverage historically that there is called an extra 10 points of incremental margin or maybe $10 million of EBIT. Should we think about that as kind of the catch up from 4Q, if I were to include that in 4Q and say that price cost or some of the other irritation items wouldn't have happened, you would have had a more normal incremental in 4Q, it looks like you're touching that rapid '19. Is that directionally fair?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's absolutely, fair. And as we've indicated on the guidance for 2019, all of the EPS growth is operational related. And it's the pressure on the item that we're getting lower-than-expected earnings per share growth. So the idea here is th
componenttext: Yes, I think that's absolutely, fair. And as we've indicated on the guidance for 2019, all of the EPS growth is operational related. And it's the pressure on the item that we're getting lower-than-expected earnings per share growth. So the idea here is that we're going to continue to press price to the extent we can do in the market competitive, and we believe we're well positioned to do that in 2019. The inflation dynamic is subsiding, particularly on the material side. That will benefit us as well. We've got a strong pipeline of productivity actions that we're going to implement. We've got some areas of opportunity for improvement, I call it self-help on the M&A integration that we performed lower than anticipated. And then we initiated some restructuring activities that will help reduce our cost base as well. So collectively, when you add all that together, I think, we're well positioned to execute on margin improvements across all regions of the business. And I feel pretty good and relative to the guide, it should help us get back to the kind of the 2017 margins that we enjoyed in that year.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, I think, I put a lot on the business in 2018, 7 acquisition. We really pressed hard on of the digitization and as we prepare to refresh our strategic plan, and went through our budgets to prepare for 2019, it really puts heavy emphasi
componenttext: Just to add to that, I think, I put a lot on the business in 2018, 7 acquisition. We really pressed hard on of the digitization and as we prepare to refresh our strategic plan, and went through our budgets to prepare for 2019, it really puts heavy emphasis of execution and focus, and I think will get that leverage back for 2017 operating margins.

Should we expect more emphasis on M&A because you did raise dividend very nicely, but that's still fairly small? Or how do you think about in 2019 M&A versus buybacks, given where the stock prices?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would start out by saying, from a capital structure perspective, as you guys know, we ended the year in the best position in terms of our leverage ratio, which provides us with a lot of optionality and flexibility going forward. I think we're we
componenttext: Yes, so I would start out by saying, from a capital structure perspective, as you guys know, we ended the year in the best position in terms of our leverage ratio, which provides us with a lot of optionality and flexibility going forward. I think we're well positioned there. If you look at our capital allocation strategy, 3 pillars; organic investment, M&A, shareholder distribution. On the organic investments, we talked about that we're going to continue to invest in the business opportunities that will expand our channel presence, getting more of the world from our distribution base as well as expanding new products through R&D efforts and those types of things, promotional items, demand creation. That's baked in our earnings per share, and we'll continue to manage that with nice earnings growth going forward. So your question on the M&A, I mean, as Dave mentioned, we executed a lot of acquisitions in 2018. There is opportunities to continue to drive performance in those and spend maybe a little bit more time, continued to integrate those. And if you look at our history, in terms of acquisition performance, they really start perform nicely in kind of 2 to 3 years out you have to look at this from a long-term basis, and we'll continue to drive that execution. Having said that, we will continue to remain active and looking at opportunities to expand our business either through new products or geographic expansion. Our pipeline remains robust. But the key is will be discipline. And we will only do transactions that we believe will provide a good return on invested capital going forward for us. Shareholder distribution, we're not going to forecast. We've already said, we're going to said utilize the capital that we generate to either do M&A or shareholder distributions through the incremental dividend. You mentioned 29% increase this year, and you can probably see us being more active on share buyback right now, and we're going to execute our capital allocation strategy to provide the best return we can for our shareholders going forward. That could be either M&A or shareholder distribution or a combination of there.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019

If that picks up acceleration, we think we're in a good position to benefit from that.

componenttext: Yes, so I would characterize it this way. As Dave said, continuous improvement to get to kind of our top competitor in that market landscape, would require either significant facility rationalization and/or scale getting more back-office synergies those types of things would certainly facilitate that. But there's still opportunities for continuous improvement, and we will continue to drive that.

So it seemed to be more project related. Did you have some comments in Q3 and then something for the end of Q4. Is that the right way to think about it? Or can you clarify that?

componenttext: You should think about it is project related. Remember, we put up a 30 in Q3, which was pretty impressive, the steam came out of that. I think, when you think about our electronics growth, I'd look at on multiple quarters. We continue to be at the high-teens level in the market that we think is converting at maybe 7% to 8%.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019

componenttext: Okay. And then just on the inflation side. So on the raw side, the finished components side, it seemed like you're going to need some tailwind here starting sometime in the first half. Is this really more a labor freight issue that's what it sounds like and the productivity initiatives I imagine you're gearing towards that. Can you give us some more color around that?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: So on the inflation side, on the material specifically, commodities kind of a mix bag still steel still remains higher than the prior year levels. However, zinc and brass and some other major imports into our products lower and so it's collectively, we're
componenttext: So on the inflation side, on the material specifically, commodities kind of a mix bag still steel still remains higher than the prior year levels. However, zinc and brass and some other major imports into our products lower and so it's collectively, we're not quite at a point right now where the year-over-year is going to show significant improvement. It's going to be more back-end loaded, I would say, the materials and then you do have the continued inflation just on the normal operational stuff. So think about it across the board whether it be salaries on personnel, freight, packaging, all these types of input cost throughout the supply chain to get our product customers are we are experiencing increased cost relative to the prior year. So we will continue to manage that for cost containment and/or driving productivity whether it be CapEx spending or other measures to get to continued efficiencies in our manufacturing footprint.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019

componenttext: Okay. And then one last clarification with regards to guide, is there a number you can think about in terms of M&A, EPS contribution from 2018 and the 2019. I assume it's within this $0.62 to $0.70 of operations, but just curious what you expect the '18 expectations to add?

componenttext: So minimal, because most of them already elapsed. Okay? So most of the acquisitions for Americas has now lapsed itself. Europe is like 1 month, additional month in there. So there is not any really incremental benefit in 2019 related to 2018 acquisition. I think the key point to mention in the guide, it doesn't assume any additional M&A activity, which would be accretive to earnings and/or share purchases. That's kind of look it from an organic basis, and that could be executed appropriately some additional earnings growth.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019

componenttext: Just wanted to get a little more color around the $0.15 of incremental investments kind of where they live as we think about the segments? And I know, you talked about broadly new product and channel initiatives, but maybe you could also specifically speak about some of those channel initiatives in residential, if that's growing a broader presence in certain retailers on how you think about the strategies?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: So the $0.15 on the incremental investments is distributed really basis of the size of the region. So, therefore, you would have a higher emphasis investment in Americas relative to your Europe and Asia. They're a specific around driving new product devel
componenttext: So the $0.15 on the incremental investments is distributed really basis of the size of the region. So, therefore, you would have a higher emphasis investment in Americas relative to your Europe and Asia. They're a specific around driving new product development, putting more emphasis on resources and engineering to accelerate new products out to the market faster. The channel initiatives, so think of demand creation really trying to accelerate electronics growth, whether it be both in the resi and/or nonresidential segments, that will continue to do that. Those would be the key items as you kind of look at phasing in 2019, a little bit more front-end loaded in our plan for 2019 than what you might have historically seen. So we'll continue to invest in the business with their believe will provide good growth opportunities, good cash on cash payback as well as a return on capital.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: I would say, in terms of specific initiatives to grow in resi, more segmentation in the market, I mentioned earlier that we're picking up some wins with the big builders. We think that's driven by our electronic capabilities. Multi-family, we'll continue
componenttext: I would say, in terms of specific initiatives to grow in resi, more segmentation in the market, I mentioned earlier that we're picking up some wins with the big builders. We think that's driven by our electronic capabilities. Multi-family, we'll continue to be strong in 2019, and this, again, we're electronic access is of value created for those residential operators and then working with the big box in terms of point of display and inventory destocking and make sure that we got the production the shelves that will help pull through with the sales of our products.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then as a follow up, you've talked about investments kind of being front-end loaded here. When we think about the price cost productivity, you mentioned that in the back half kind of actually looks like deflation on some of the material costs
componenttext: Got you. And then as a follow up, you've talked about investments kind of being front-end loaded here. When we think about the price cost productivity, you mentioned that in the back half kind of actually looks like deflation on some of the material costs. How should we think about the quarterly cadence of the first half, second half relative to normal history of anything you normally do about 47% of your OP and EPS in the first half, given those dynamic should we think that, that deviates a little bit? Or is that still a normal seasonality is still the right way to think about it?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Maybe a little bit more back-end loaded. I think it's interesting on the growth side of things, which we get pretty good operating leverage on growth coming out of the gate. Q1 is always a little bit lighter relative to our overall growth and then acceler
componenttext: Maybe a little bit more back-end loaded. I think it's interesting on the growth side of things, which we get pretty good operating leverage on growth coming out of the gate. Q1 is always a little bit lighter relative to our overall growth and then accelerates in Q2, Q3, kind of relative to the seasonality of our business. And we saw some good acceleration in Q4. So I would kind of think about in the same type of pattern, but from a margin contribution perspective, with the inflation kind of subsiding more in the back end of the year, so look at a heavier mix of operational improvement in the second half relative to first half.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: I would add to that, we're very intensional in our 2019 budgeting. I think we've got the activities that will drive margin expansion throughout the year, but the nature of it, some of these products will go over multi-quarters, and will pick up momentum a
componenttext: I would add to that, we're very intensional in our 2019 budgeting. I think we've got the activities that will drive margin expansion throughout the year, but the nature of it, some of these products will go over multi-quarters, and will pick up momentum as the year goes on.

componenttext: I'd say, government shutdown, we were more heavily impacted by weather when mechanical installers can't get on the job site, even you see that. There's parts of the country that having some pretty tough challenges, and we'll see that as it envelopes -- develops. But I'd hang there on the weather versus government shutdown.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the tariff exposure and what's built into your guidance?
componenttext: Can you talk about the tariff exposure and what's built into your guidance?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: So all tariff exposure is built into the guidance basis on what we know today. We'll see and monitor how that develops going forward. I think, you've heard us talk previously that we don't have a lot of exposure because we source manufacturer itself prett
componenttext: So all tariff exposure is built into the guidance basis on what we know today. We'll see and monitor how that develops going forward. I think, you've heard us talk previously that we don't have a lot of exposure because we source manufacturer itself pretty much in region for products that we do import from China to the extent that they're exposed to tariffs beginning in March. That's baked into our guidance. However, as we've indicated, we are mitigating the impact of the, either through price increase that we instituted late last year and/or productivity resourcing, those types of things to minimize those impacts. But all of that has baked in. So the favorable outcome could be some upside going forward.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: First, maybe just housekeeping one for me on for Patrick. Patrick, you're guiding that tax rate up year-over-year, but I think, down certain what I was thinking, I'm not sure what the street was, but to make sure my question is we've seen a number of non-
componenttext: First, maybe just housekeeping one for me on for Patrick. Patrick, you're guiding that tax rate up year-over-year, but I think, down certain what I was thinking, I'm not sure what the street was, but to make sure my question is we've seen a number of non-U.S. companies here recently signaling that they're up on the deductibility of interest expense. And are kind of suggesting the tax rates are going to be up doesn't seem like that's here in 2019, but do you have any color on that? And why that may or may not be impacting your situation?

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I can't really obviously comment on other companies by particular tax situation, but maybe the general comment is the relative to some of these proposed regulations that we issued at the end of the year. They're extremely complex. And as we said,
componenttext: Yes, so I can't really obviously comment on other companies by particular tax situation, but maybe the general comment is the relative to some of these proposed regulations that we issued at the end of the year. They're extremely complex. And as we said, it can foreign domiciled companies as well as multinational companies. So maybe your commentary is kind of caught up in that. I think there's going to be a lot of commentary, and we'll see kind of where that ends up, but relative to Allegion, we evaluated those extensively with our outside advisers, and we've made some necessary tweaks, necessary to kind of feel pretty good relative to our 16% effective tax rate guide for 2019. We'll see where it goes going forward, but I think we're okay for '19. And as it relates to interest deductibility, relative to the U.S. tax reform in 2017, that does impact us a little bit from a cash tax perspective, and that's baked in our available cash flow numbers. So our cash taxes because of some of the limitation will always be higher than our book provision.

componenttext: And that's helpful. componenttext: I don't see that, Jeff. We've gotten a nice position out of the Baja that we think sets that up nicely. Our electronics are built there, and we think the superior access to market and be able to get those in production quickly really helps us. So we feel good about our position.

componenttext: Maybe just kind of touching on the Americas organic guide for a second. Is there a way to maybe parse that out a little bit further. You guys talk a little bit about softening in new construction, resi new construction, but is the expectation in that resi new is going to be down and then any other color around in different markets and the build up to that guide would be helpful.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: So our view on residential new construction is softer in 2019 versus '18. I think we mitigate that somewhat to our electronics offering and our strong position in retrofit. As we move to the noninstitutional, we continue to see strength in the education m
componenttext: So our view on residential new construction is softer in 2019 versus '18. I think we mitigate that somewhat to our electronics offering and our strong position in retrofit. As we move to the noninstitutional, we continue to see strength in the education market, which is K-12 and college campuses. That's one of our strongholds 2 things working there, you've got continued investment and electronic conversion. We think health care continues to be a good opportunity for the company, not so much in the big hospitals, but in the trend to go to smaller medical suites, diagnostic centers, those types of things that you see happening nationwide and then commercial offices continue to be okay. As I travel around the country, and I have extensively in the last 75 days, I feel good pulse in the commercial and institutional campuses, and that's reflected in how we see our growth in '19.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Dave day. And if I can maybe follow-up I'm just talking about EMEIA for a second. Any other additional color you can provide on QMI, specifically and as it relates to the broader margin kind of targeting in that business for '19. Sho
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Dave day. And if I can maybe follow-up I'm just talking about EMEIA for a second. Any other additional color you can provide on QMI, specifically and as it relates to the broader margin kind of targeting in that business for '19. Should we expect just like this is the acceleration of margins can you get the double digits in '19 any thoughts that would be helpful.

headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, so obviously the QMI performance was disappointing in the quarter. Tough market conditions and that business is a longer earnings process. So think of installation work and when jobs get deferred for whatever reason, you kind of settle with a fixed c
componenttext: Yes, so obviously the QMI performance was disappointing in the quarter. Tough market conditions and that business is a longer earnings process. So think of installation work and when jobs get deferred for whatever reason, you kind of settle with a fixed costs that hit us in the quarter. We're taking action to mitigate some of those cost going forward and we'd expect sequential improvement continuous throughout the year to get back to profitability. So that will start being reported obviously in base business beginning in the quarter after Europe. So think of Europe in aggregate, along with the rest of the business with continuous margin improvement during the course of the year either through better performance on this QMI business specifically and/or productivity, the price and inflation dynamic getting better and so you'll see us back close to that double-digit operating profit margin for the full year.

componenttext: I believe -- as I look at our backlogs, they remain healthy. More importantly, the stock and remain healthy on both of these verticals. I wouldn't characterize it as an acceleration. I just think as we continue to drive portfolio expansion through new products and acquisitions like TGP as well as superior execution and working these more complex applications, we tend to get more than our fair share. componenttext: Okay. One follow-up is just against your 2 major competitors over in Europe, you're somewhat of a new be with regards to commercial door manufacturing business. headline: Allegion plc, Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2019
componenttextpreview: So we have been in the metal business since 1970. So this is something under the Steelcraft. We're pretty knowledgeable of the space. I think as we moved into the Middle East look back into the acquisition, number one, you've got market turbulence with so
componenttext: So we have been in the metal business since 1970. So this is something under the Steelcraft. We're pretty knowledgeable of the space. I think as we moved into the Middle East look back into the acquisition, number one, you've got market turbulence with some of the political instability in the Middle East. Number two, there was a pretty big change in the mix of business under the previous ownership that was target on that moved. And then third, you've got to be mindful, I don't care if you look at the world are hollow metal business, these are top areas to operate. So we're mindful of that. We believe that the acquisition of QMI went public and what we've done with 80 systems with this is slightly capability complement our strategy will give those integrated and outperform to our satisfaction in the future.
